entry.title: Re: PO custom delivery address not populating for limit l...
entry.content:
In SAP’s standard form logic for purchase orders, limit items (used in service procurement or value-based contracts) are handled differently:

They are often represented in a separate node in the form data provider class (e.g., LimitItem, ServiceItem, etc.).
The extension point MM_PUR_S4_PO_MODIFY_ITEM modifies the standard item node, not the limit item node.
Since you cannot extend the data source, you’re unable to inject custom fields directly into the LimitItem node.

Below are some workaround options:

Use a Shared Custom Field in the Header or Item Node. If extending the LimitItem node is blocked, consider adding the custom delivery address to a shared field in the PO Item node (which is accessible). Then, in the Adobe Form logic, use a lookup or mapping to associate the correct address with the limit item based on item number or description. This requires a custom script in the Adobe Form to match the limit item with its corresponding address. Possibly storing the address in a text field or unused field that is accessible in both nodes.

If the form cannot access the custom field directly, store the custom delivery address in a custom table keyed by PO number and item number. Create a CDS view or OData service that reads this table. In the Adobe Form, use a secondary data source to fetch the address dynamically. This approach avoids extending the form’s primary data source and keeps logic modular.

In some S/4HANA Cloud environments, SAP allows master data enhancements via form templates. You can define a custom master data source that includes delivery addresses. Then bind it to the form using context mapping. This is limited but worth checking in your environment.

See the below table

entry.title: Re: Need Solution to Post SAC Plan Data (Cost Element 43)...
entry.content:
Hello @brahmareddy_kolli 

For your need to post SAC plan data for Cost Element Category 43, including sender and receiver cost centers, into ECC

  1. In ECC (Planning)
    • There’s no single T-code equivalent to KB21N for plan postings.
    • You can utilise standard plan input transactions such as KP06 for costs and KP26 for activity quantities, or alternatively, use BAPIs like:
      • BAPI_COSTCENTER_PLN_COSTS – for planning costs.
      • BAPI_COSTCENTER_PLN_ACTINPUT_QTY – for planning activity quantities.
    • After posting data, utilise allocation cycles (KSVP/KSVB) to allocate planned activity quantities between sender and receiver costs centers.
  2. From SAC to ECC
    • SAP Analytics Cloud lacks a built-in write-back connector for ECC plan data, unlike those available for S/4HANA or BW.
    • Integration is usually carried out through custom CPI/PI/PO or Cloud Connector RFC calls that invoke the BAPIs mentioned above to load plan data into ECC.
    • This method allows passing sender and receiver cost centers along with Cost Element Category 43, as long as the relevant planning version is open in ECC.

SAP Documentation SAC Integration Overview

You can meet the requirement, but it will require a custom integration layer to post from SAC to ECC using planning BAPIs. There’s no standard SAC → ECC write-back scenario available.

Let me know if you need further support

With regards

Chuma

entry.title: Seamless Multi-Company Data Replication in SAP Field Service Management - Blog Series
entry.content:
Seamless Multi-Company Data Replication in SAP Field Service Management - Part 1

The SAP Field Service Management (FSM) landscape is built on two key components: the Account and the Company. While the Account acts as the highest organizational level, a Company represents a specific legal entity, department, or business unit. This structure allows customers to manage multiple companies within a single FSM system to align with their business units. However, this creates a common challenge—replicating data from SAP S/4HANA to multiple FSM Companies. Data replication rules often vary depending on factors like Sales Area, Plant, Company Code, or Purchasing Group.

The standard integration content previously had a limitation, allowing data to be sent to only one FSM company at a time from S/4HANA Public or Private Cloud systems. With the 2023 FPS03 release, this limitation has been addressed—enabling standard integration from S/4HANA to multiple FSM Companies.

In this blog series, I’ll explore this new multi-company integration capability for both from S/4HANA public and private cloud system perspective. I’ll also share edge cases where implementing custom logic can help determine the correct FSM Company based on incoming S/4HANA data.

Blog Series links:

Part 1 - Multiple Company integration overview and preparing S/4HANA systems for Multi-Company Integration

Part 2 - Configurations in CPI and Special handling of Business objects in Multiple Company integration

Part 3 - Achieving Multiple Company integration through custom logic implementation and enhanced error logging

These multiple company data integration features are available in the latest version of standard integration content:

SAP S/4HANA Integration with SAP Field Service Management

Integration of Service in SAP S/4HANA Cloud with SAP Field Service Management

 

Supported Data objects for multiple FSM company integration from S/4HANA systems:

Object Name

S/4HANA Public Cloud System

S/4HANA Private Cloud System

Business Partner, Address, Contact and Relationship

Yes (via SAP CPI)

Yes (via SAP CPI)

Product, Product Price and Stock

Yes (via SAP CPI)

Yes (via SAP CPI)

Material Group, Employee, Service Employee Assignment to warehouse

No

Yes (via SAP CPI)

Service Order

Yes (via SAP CPI)

Yes (via SAP CPI)

Service Contract

Yes (Point to Point integration)

Yes (Point to Point integration)

Equipment

No

Yes (Point to Point integration)

Functional Location

No

Yes (Point to Point integration)

Equipment and Functional location Classification

No

Yes (Point to Point integration)

 

Maintain Mapping rules:

As a first step, we need to configure the mapping rules to identify the FSM company id based for the incoming business data. These multiple company mapping rules should be maintained in S/4HANA system.

S/4HANA Public Cloud setup:

In S/4HANA public cloud, open “Manage Your Solution” app, then click on Configure Your Solution. Search for “Integration with SAP Field Service Management” item to configure Multiple Company Replication. If this item is not visible in your solution management, then set the local version to USA.

Here you can define the Rule type for each Business object, there are multiple rule type options available for you to choose like below:

Rule Type Code

Rule Type Field

Description

0

All Companies

Object will be replicated to all defined FSM companies in the configuration

1

Plant

Object will be replicated based on the plant data in the source data

2

Sales Area

Object will be replicated based on the Sales Area data in the source data

3

Company Code

Object will be replicated based on the Company Code data in the source data

4

Purchasing Code

Object will be replicated based on the Purchasing Code data in the source data

5

Purchasing Org

Object will be replicated based on the Purchasing Group data in the source data

6

Specific Field

Object will be replicated based on any field from the source data as defined in the rule mapping. To be used when rule is defined based on non-standard rules like plant, sales area, etc as above.

Configure full list of FSM company Id along with their account id to which the data to be replicated in “Define S/4HANA FSM Company” and Assign FSM Company Details.

 

Now, assign Replication object detail for each FSM Company and relevant rule type filters like Sales Area or Plants or Company Codes, etc.

Recommended mapping configuration for standard rule types is shown as below. But this can be extended for custom rule types as per the business need.

If you configure rule type as specific field, then the relevant fields must be assign with the path of the field and its value for each company in the mapping configuration. Note: for Business Partner you must configure field path of both SOAP and Odata structure. Refer to the standard Odata and Web service structure of the business object object from SAP Business Accelerator hub.

Note to exclude the root elements from the field path. For reference, follow the below table for specific field path configuration on different object types:

Object Type

S/4HANA Private Cloud or On premise S/4HANA setup:

In On premise S/4HANA (SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud) system, the multiple company mapping configure remains almost the same but with some additional business objects for replication. Also, in addition available rule types in S/4HANA Public cloud, here you can set up the rule type as Custom Logic. When Custom logic rule type is set for any object, the FSM Company identification happens based on custom code written (requires BAPI) in S/4HANA system.

Execute the below SPRO path for the multiple company configuration.

SAP Customizing Implementation Guide -> Service -> Integration with Other SAP Solutions -> SAP Field Service Management -> Configure Multiple Company Replication

Below is the required configuration detail for each rule type.

Rule Type

Required Configuration Item

Custom Logic

No Configuration Required

All Companies

Assign FSM Company Details

Plant / Sales Area / Purchasing Group / Company Code / Purchasing Org / Service Org

Assign FSM Company Details,
Assign Relevant <Rule Type>

Specific Field

Assign FSM Company Details,

This completes the configuration required in the S/4HANA systems for the multiple company integration. Now, the mapping information should be synchronized to SAP Cloud Integration and few configurations should be enabled in the standard interfaces to make the multiple FSM company integration work.

To be continued…

Click on the below blog link for the second part: Part 2

entry.title: Seamless Multi-Company Data Replication in SAP Field Service Management – Part 3
entry.content:
Custom Logic in Pre exits and Error Handling in Multiple FSM Company Replication in SAP Cloud Integration

In this blog part, I’ll explain how to use custom exits within the multiple company fetch functionality of standard interfaces to determine the relevant FSM company. I’ll also highlight the enhanced error handling introduced in SAP Cloud Integration as part of the multiple company integration feature.

Blog Series links:

Part 1 - Multiple Company integration overview and preparing S/4HANA systems for Multi-Company Integration

Part 2 - Configurations in CPI and Special handling of Business objects in Multiple Company integration

Part 3 - Achieving Multiple Company integration through custom logic implementation and enhanced error logging

Sometimes, the standard rule types provided by SAP—such as Sales Area, Company Code, etc—may not fit your business requirements for identifying the FSM company. In such cases, you can implement your own custom logic to determine the FSM Company IDs and Account IDs for incoming data. This custom logic can be implemented in multiple ways, depending on your integration scenario and business needs.

.

Custom Logic Using Pre-Exits for Multiple Company in Standard Interfaces:

In the S/4HANA Public Cloud to SAP FSM integration, you can leverage a pre-exit to determine FSM company details dynamically.

To enable this:

  1. In the standard interface where you want to apply custom logic, set the parameter Enable Pre-Exit MultiCompany to true.
  2. Create a Process Direct interface to implement your custom logic for setting FSM Account IDs and Company IDs.
  3. Apply your business rules to assign one or multiple companies as required.

This approach gives you flexibility to map FSM companies based on your specific business criteria before the data is sent to FSM.

 

Sample custom interface with custom logic to identify the FSM company and account id for the business partner object.

In the Groovy step “Set FSM Company details”, I have logic to different FSM account and company based on country code and for the FLCU01 role code. The identified FSM account and company details are appended to the same Business Partner message as in below format.

Similarly, this logic can be extended to any extent as per your requirement.

<FSMMultiCompany>
  <FSMCompany>accountid1|companyidA</FSMCompany>
  <FSMCompany>accountid1|companyidB</FSMCompany>
  .
  .
</FSMMultiCompany>

Later in the XSLT step “XSLT Group by FSM Company”, the message is grouped per FSM account and company Id pair using xml attribute “MultiCompanyGroup” as accountid|companyid. This group of data per each FSM account and company pair is required for the further processing of the data into each FSM company by the standard interface. More detail on how to group the message is provided in the following link Multiple Company Pre-Exits.

Final payload which sent back to standard Replicate Business Partner interface is as below. The standard interface will take care of posting the BP data to each FMS company in sequential batches.

In scenario of S/4HANA Private Cloud to SAP FSM integration scenario, you can either use the similar approach of using the pre exits provided for the multiple company fetch in the standard interfaces as shown above OR you can set the rule type as “Custom” in the S/4HANA multiple company configuration for the business object and implement a BADI to identify the FSM company ID in S4HANA.

 

Custom Logic Using Custom rule type in Multiple Company config in S/4HANA:

The Custom Logic rule type is available only for integration between SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud and SAP Field Service Management (FSM).

This option allows you to determine the relevant FSM companies using your own code or logic instead of predefined rules. To use it:

  • Create an implementation for the BAdI CRMS4_FSM_RELV_COMP_DETERM.
  • Assign the Custom Logic rule type to the desired Replication Object, Attribute, and Attribute Value in the multiple company configuration.
  • Use the same combination as a filter in your BAdI implementation.
  • If Custom Logic is required for multiple replication objects, create a separate BAdI implementation for each.

Example: To configure custom logic for Sales Customers:

Step 1: Assign Custom Logic Rule Type

  • Replication Object: Business Partner (BP)
  • Replication Object Attribute: BP Role (02)
  • Replication Object Attribute Value: BP Customer – Sales (FLCU01)

Step 2: Create BAdI Implementation with Filters

  • Replication Object (REPL_OBJECT): Business Partner (BP)
  • Replication Object Attribute (OBJ_ATR): BP Role (02)
  • Replication Object Attribute Value (OBJ_ATR_VAL): BP Customer – Sales (FLCU01)

This approach gives you full flexibility to define custom company determination logic that fits your organization’s business rules, while keeping it aligned with the multiple company integration framework.

 

Enhanced Error Logging in Multi-Company integrations:

In multi-company integration scenarios, SAP Cloud Integration now provides enhanced error logging to simplify troubleshooting and root cause analysis.

When data errors occur during replication to SAP Field Service Management (FSM) companies, the system:

  • Creates attachments in the Message Processing Log (MPL) with detailed error information.
  • Records custom MPL headers indicating the FSM company for which the data failed to load.
  • Generates separate attachments for each FSM company, ensuring issue tracking is company-specific.

If an error is generic (not linked to a specific FSM company), it is still logged in a custom MPL header containing the company and account ID, along with relevant attachments.

Handling Missing Company Assignments

When no FSM company can be determined for an incoming replication object, the object is filtered out and not sent to any FSM company.

  • These filtered object IDs are recorded in a dedicated custom MPL header.
  • All attachment file names are suffixed with the corresponding FSM company ID.
  • If multiple companies are determined for one replication object, separate attachments are created for each.

 

Custom MPL Headers in Multi-Company Error Handling

Custom Header

Value

Purpose

FSMCompanyNotFoundForBusinessPartner

Business Partner ID

Logs BP ID filtered out due to no matching FSM company

FSMCompanyNotFoundForBusinessPartnerRelationWithContact

Business Partner ID | Contact ID

Logs BP & Contact IDs filtered out due to no matching FSM company

FSMCompanyNotFoundForProduct

Product ID

Logs Product ID filtered out due to no matching FSM company

FSMCompanyNotFoundForWarehouse

Product ID | Plant | Storage Location

Logs Product, Plant & Storage Location filtered out

FSMCompanyNotFoundForConditionRecord

Condition Record ID

Logs Condition Record ID filtered out

FSMCompanyNotFoundForServiceOrder

Service Order ID

Logs Service Order ID filtered out

BusinessPartnerFailedToLoad

Business Partner ID | FSM Company ID

Logs BP ID & company ID for FSM load errors

ContactFailedToLoad

Contact ID | FSM Company ID

Logs Contact ID & company ID for FSM load errors

BusinessPartnerRelationFailedToLoad

Contact ID | FSM Company ID

Logs Contact ID & company ID for relationship replication errors

ProductFailedtoLoad

Product ID | FSM Company ID

Logs Product ID & company ID for FSM load errors

WarehouseFailedtoLoad

Warehouse External ID

Logs Warehouse external ID & company ID for FSM load errors

ItemWarehouseFailedtoLoad

Item Warehouse External ID

Logs Item Warehouse external ID & company ID for FSM load errors

PriceListFailedtoLoad

Price List External ID

Logs Price List external ID & company ID for FSM load errors

ItemPriceListFailedtoLoad

Item | Price List ID

Logs Item & Price List external ID & company ID for FSM load errors

ServiceOrderFailedtoLoad

Service Order ID | FSM Company ID

Logs Service Order ID & company ID for FSM load errors

DataFailedtoLoad

FSM Account ID | FSM Company ID

Logs FSM account & company ID for non-FSM specific errors

 

This improved logging framework ensures that every failure—whether company-specific or generic—is captured with context, allowing for faster resolution in complex multi-company setups.

Sample error logging snapshots:

entry.title: Re: SAP Document and Reporting Compliance Malaysia Digita...
entry.content:
Hello , 

Thank you for the detailed explanation. We understand there are concerns regarding the current XML version in Public Cloud (v1.0) and the digital signature requirements applicable only in v1.1.

Following our latest discussions and verification with LHDN (IRBM):

  • Both v1.0 and v1.1 are currently accepted.
  • There is no official plan or timeline yet for mandatory migration from v1.0 to v1.1.

What this means for you:

  • You can continue using v1.0 without digital signatures and remain compliant.
  • Our team is reviewing how SAP DRC should handle certificate/key pair requirements in v1.0 scenarios to align with actual technical needs.
  • To avoid blocking your tests, you can generate a self-signed certificate and upload it under your TIN in the DRC Communication Settings. This will allow connections to IRBM to work.

We will share updates once a confirmed approach or enhancement is available for Public Cloud. In case you have further question, please contact the SAP support team via your usual channels. Thank you.

entry.title: Re: Finance BCS Quarter closing impacted due to issue (du...
entry.content:
Hello @Girish_Jadhav49 

In BCS (Business Consolidation), auto-generated elimination entries cannot be deleted; instead, they must be reversed using the same elimination process that created them

  • Determine the specific elimination task or method responsible for creating the duplicate entry during the consolidation process monitor.
  • Re-execute the task in reversal mode for the relevant period, such as June 2025. This will generate the reversing entry.
  • Then, run the task again in normal mode to post the correct elimination entry.
  • If entries from previous periods, such as March 2025, were mistakenly reversed in June, you can fix this by creating a new manual consolidation journal or by modifying the task settings as needed.

This process uses the standard BCS workflow and does not require unsupported notes.

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: Association from picklist (Employee Class) to Generic...
entry.content:
Hello,

I understand your query regarding establishing a parent-child relationship between `Picklist` and a Generic Object. At this time, it is not feasible to create such a relationship either through an association or any other method.

To successfully establish a parent-child relationship, it is essential that both fields involved share the same data type. This means that both the parent and child fields must either be Generic Objects or Picklists.

For further guidance, you may find the following resources helpful: -

- **How to create association between GOs on MDF objects:**  - 2172234 - Association not working while creating a position - SAP for Me
- **How to create cascading picklists in MDF Objects:** - 2352794 - How to create cascading picklists in MDF Objects? - SAP for Me

Regards,
Indumati

entry.title: Asset Management in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508
entry.content:
Welcome to the blog post for asset management in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 release! This release delivers a series of targeted enhancements in maintenance management, aimed at improving operational workflows, data accuracy, and planning precision.

Table of Contents
  • New manage maintenance notification app (F5777)
  • E-mail reminders: Deadline monitoring for maintenance order flexible workflow
  • Partner and warranty support in manage material serial numbers app
  • Refresh button in manage maintenance backlog
  • Filter by plan status in manage maintenance items
  • Copy maintenance plan in manage maintenance plans
  • Display warranty details in maintenance order apps
  • Supplier material number in maintenance order apps
  • Authorization group field in maintenance plan migration template
  • System condition at operation level in task list odata API
  • C1 release of CDS view for task list operations with PRT
  • Origin indicator in measurement document API

More information / additional links

Before delving into each feature, I invite you to watch the release highlights video below. This time, my digital twin presents what is new for Asset Management in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 release:

 

Let’s start with the first three innovations showcased in the video above

New manage maintenance notification app (F5777)

The brand-new “Manage Maintenance Notification” app (F5777) consolidates the entire maintenance notification lifecycle into a single, role-based Fiori application. It replaces multiple legacy apps by offering a unified interface for creation, screening, editing, and follow-up actions. Users can now create notifications in draft mode, scan equipment barcodes, attach documents, and assign task lists or orders, all within one app.

The app supports notifications of types M1, M2, and M3, and introduces flexible role handling, allowing users with multiple responsibilities to operate without switching roles. Additionally, a new BAdI enables dynamic UI field control, allowing fields to be made mandatory or read-only based on context, such as notification priority or subphase.

This app significantly streamlines maintenance processes, enhances user productivity, and supports extensibility through custom logic.

Watch the demo below to learn more details with Akif Ünal:

 

Back to table of contents

E-mail reminders: Deadline monitoring for maintenance order flexible workflow

To improve workflow compliance and reduce delays in order approvals, SAP has introduced deadline monitoring for maintenance order workflows. This feature ensures that approvers are reminded to act on pending workflow items either through visual indicators in the SAP inbox or via email alerts.

The email notification mechanism is configurable during workflow definition and uses a standard SAP template, which customers can customize through the extensibility framework. By enabling proactive alerts, this enhancement helps prevent bottlenecks in maintenance execution, supports SLA adherence, and improves overall workflow responsiveness.

Watch the demo below to learn more details with Akif Ünal:

 

Back to table of contents

Partner and warranty support in manage material serial numbers app

The Manage Material Serial Numbers (F6879) app has been enhanced to support the assignment of both partner and warranty details to serialized materials. Users can now select partner functions and IDs using F4 value help, linking business partners directly to serial numbers. Additionally, warranty information (including type, master warranty number, validity dates, and inheritance flags) can be assigned to each serial number.

This capability strengthens asset traceability and ensures that warranty entitlements and partner responsibilities are clearly defined at the serial number level. It’s particularly valuable for industries with serialized equipment and complex service networks.

Watch the demo below to learn more details:

 

Back to table of contents

Now, moving to further innovations for 2508 release:

Refresh button in manage maintenance backlog

In the Manage Maintenance Backlog Fiori app (F4073), a new refresh button has been introduced to allow users to update the list of orders within a specific bucket without reloading the entire page. Previously, when an order’s status changed, such as resolving an issue that had marked it red, the application did not reflect the update unless the user performed a full-page refresh.

This enhancement enables a table-level refresh, fetching the latest status directly from the backend and updating the UI accordingly. The result is a smoother user experience, faster validation of order changes, and improved data accuracy, especially in high-volume maintenance environments. This change supports more responsive backlog management and reduces unnecessary page reloads, which can be disruptive in operational contexts.

Refresh button in manage maintenance backlog

Back to table of contents

Filter by plan status in manage maintenance items

The Manage Maintenance Items app (F5356) now supports filtering based on Maintenance Plan Status, allowing users to isolate items by their lifecycle state. Available filter options include "Created", "Inactive", and "Deletion Flag". It’s important to note that "Scheduled" is treated as "Created" since it is a calculated status rather than a system-defined one.

This enhancement enables maintenance planners and technicians to focus on relevant items, avoid processing those marked for deletion, and streamline planning activities by narrowing down the dataset to actionable entries. By introducing this filter, we improve the precision of maintenance item selection and supports better decision-making in planning and execution phases.

Watch the demo below to learn more details:

 

Back to table of contents

Copy maintenance plan in manage maintenance plans

The Manage Maintenance Plans (F5325) app now supports direct copying of maintenance plans, streamlining the creation of similar plans without relying on predefined templates. Unlike the Process Maintenance Plans app, which required users to create and use copy templates, this enhancement allows any maintenance plan to be copied flexibly from the list page.

Users can select a plan, initiate the copy action, and define parameters such as scheduling options, maintenance items, and object lists. The copied plan is created in draft mode, allowing for review and adjustments before finalization. This feature simplifies plan replication, reduces setup time, and supports faster onboarding of new assets or maintenance strategies.

Watch the demo below to learn more details:

 

Back to table of contents

Display warranty details in maintenance order apps

Maintenance technicians and planners can now view warranty information for technical objects directly within the Create, Change, and Display Maintenance Order applications, also in Fiori interface. A new "show warranty" button reveals warranty details associated with the technical object linked to the order.

This visibility allows users to quickly assess whether a component is under warranty before initiating repairs or replacements, potentially reducing costs and avoiding unnecessary work. The integration of warranty data into the order context enhances decision-making and supports more informed maintenance planning.

2. Display warranty details in maintenance order apps

Back to table of contents

Supplier material number in maintenance order apps

Maintenance Order applications (Create, Change, Display, and Find) now support the display and update of Supplier Material Numbers (SMN) within the "Material and Services" tab. This enhancement ensures that supplier-specific part numbers are visible and traceable throughout the maintenance process.

By integrating SMNs into the order context, SAP enables better alignment with procurement documents such as purchase requisitions and purchase orders, where supplier part numbers are often critical. This feature enhances traceability, reduces errors in material identification, and supports smoother collaboration with external vendors.

3. Supplier material number in maintenance order apps

Back to table of contents

Authorization group field in maintenance plan migration template

The Maintenance Plan migration template has been enhanced to include the Authorization Group (BEGRP) field, along with fields for scheduling end date and end counter. These additions allow customers to migrate maintenance plans from external systems while preserving access control and scheduling boundaries.

This is particularly beneficial for organizations transitioning from ECC or legacy ERP systems that used authorization groups to restrict access to specific plans. By enabling these fields in the migration template, SAP reduces the need for post-migration mass updates and supports a more secure and complete data transfer process.

System condition at operation level in task list odata API

In previous releases, the "System Condition" field was not available at the operation level in the Task List OData API, limiting the ability to retrieve this critical information. With the 2508 release, this field has been added to the API, allowing external systems and custom applications to access system condition data for each operation.

This enhancement improves integration capabilities and supports more detailed analysis and automation scenarios, especially in environments where system condition influences task execution or prioritization.

C1 release of CDS view for task list operations with PRT

SAP has introduced a new C1-released CDS view to support the extraction of task list operations along with their assigned Production Resource Tools (PRTs). This view is derived from the I_MaintTaskListOpPRT CDS and includes the most relevant fields consolidated into an intermediary analytical view.

Previously, customers lacked a standard report or app to bulk retrieve this data. The new CDS view addresses this gap, enabling efficient reporting and integration for maintenance planning and execution. It provides a structured way to access task list and PRT data, supporting better resource allocation and operational transparency.

Origin indicator in measurement document API

The Measurement Document API has been enhanced to include the "MeasurementDocumentOrigin" property, which indicates the source of a measurement entry. This field allows systems to distinguish between manually entered readings, API-based entries, batch inputs, and other origins.

By exposing this metadata, we enable more transparent data tracking and supports future use cases where the origin of a measurement may influence validation, reporting, or automation logic. This enhancement improves data governance and supports integration scenarios where origin traceability is essential.

Learn more about it: API Reference | Measurement Document | SAP Business Accelerator Hub

Back to table of contents

entry.title: Display the story date filter value, and display in table control as column
entry.content:
Trying to read either inputcontrol_1 values or story parameter values, and combine them with a few other modeler dimension columns to create a variable called VarConcatV1.

To display as a column in a table control.

Here are the steps:

1. Create a list of variables

V_LastDayOfMonth = FormatDate(LastDayOfMonth([PayrollEndDate_Input]);"yyyyMMdd")

VarConcatV1 = "[E Code]+"010" + [V_LastDayOfMonth]+ [P1 Number] + Concatentation("XXXXX"; [Identity Number]) + Left([LastName];1) + [LastName]

2. Create a new SAC story page with a table control that displays a list of columns as shown below.
---------------------

VarConcatV1 | [First Name] | varDaysWorked | [Paid Amount] | [R Amount | [L Amt] | [A Amount] | [T1]

 

Thanks

entry.title: Re: SAP B2B TPM routing of EDIFACT application reference
entry.content:
Hi @briankrogh_nielsen 

Thank you for your question. Let me walk you through it.

You cannot create two flows with the same message type on a single TPM Partner Agreement in standard SAP configuration. However, you can work around this requirement by adding a custom routing or mapping logic based on the Application Reference (e.g., PICK or PACK) from the UNB segment.

I suggest you follow this approach

First, design and deploy a custom mapping iFlow in SAP Integration Suite that examines the incoming EDI message, reads the Application Reference in the UNB segment and then routes the message to the appropriate mapping logic.

Thereafter, you can parse the UNB segment, check its application reference, and direct the process flow accordingly using ProcessDirect endpoints.

Create separate MIGs for each business scenario and call the relevant mapping inside the iFlow based on this value.

When processing the EDI file, set a header variable with the value from UNB Application Reference, then implement a router or condition in your flow to map to the correct destination or use the appropriate transformation logic.

Finally, make sure you maintain a single Partner Agreement but add the necessary logic in your integration flow to route based on the distinguishing field in the UNB segment.

 

To summarize, while TPM does not allow two flows with the same message type for the same partner, you can handle your requirement by configuring your integration flows to inspect the Application Reference value and direct to the appropriate PICK or PACK mapping.

I hope this provides the necessary information. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Failed to create a source system based on SAP S/4HANA...
entry.content:
Hi @mikeneko1977 

The issue you are facing is a common problem often caused by changes in the global key or system data, which then invalidates stored passwords in the secure storage, user password expiration, lock, or incorrect password maintained in the RFC destination and the background user assigned to the RFC destination may be locked or have insufficient authorization.

To resolve that I recommend considering the following steps:

First thing is to check and update the RFC user password. Go to transaction SM59 in BW and edit the RFC destination for DEVCLNT110, re-enter and save the correct password for the background user and then test the connection and authorization using the options in SM59 to confirm validity.

Second, you need to unlock or reset the user in S/4HANA. Verify the background user is not locked or expired on the S/4HANA system, reset password if needed and ensure user has the necessary authorizations and

Then, clear secure storage or refresh credentials. Sometimes secure storage in BW caches stale credentials. Delete and recreate the RFC destination if necessary.

Thereafter, check ABAP short dumps. Analyse dumps related to CALL_FUNCTION_REMOTE_ERROR and logon failures to identify additional details.

Finally, ensure your system landscape and client settings are correct. To do this, confirm the target system in RFC points correctly to the intended S/4HANA system and client.

By following these steps, you should be able to resolve the invalid password issue and successfully create the source system connection in BW.

I hope this provides the necessary information. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Embedded RSSD compatibility and performance
entry.content:
Hi @Adam_Friedman 

To answer your question, yes it is technically possible for you to have a replication domain with both classic and embedded RSSDs but you have to consider certain details. Classic ASE-based RSSDs and embedded RSSDs have different architectures and management requirements for it to function. They may have different capabilities, and some features might only be fully supported or optimized on embedded RSSDs. It’s important to check compatibility and support status for your version and scenario.

Embedded RSSDs typically offer improvements in management and monitoring versus classic RSSDs. However, performance impact depends on the workload, data volume, and number of queues or routes you aim for. With heavy data flow approx.15GB per day and multiple queues/routes per server, careful sizing, monitoring and possibly hardware resource planning is needed to avoid bottlenecks. Embedded RSSDs also reduce overhead by managing replication agent processes internally.

The summary of this all is tht you can mix RSSD types but be mindful of their differences and test for your specific workload. Embedded RSSDs offer improved integration and manageability but scale planning is crucial for your expected high data volumes.

I hope this provides the necessary information. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: SAP Community Voice: Popular Posts, Blog It Forward, Site Updates, and More
entry.content:
We were really happy to see the positive response to the relaunch of our online SAP Community Voice newsletter. Based on this reaction, we’re aiming to deliver two newsletters per month, following the same cadence as the retired email version. That means every few weeks (likely on the 15th and final day of every month), we’ll publish a post in What’s New to highlight popular member-contributed content, a summary of important community news, a look at upcoming events, and more.

Enjoy this latest edition, and we’ll be back before the end of August with another newsletter!

 

Featured Content

 

SAP Datasphere Replication Flow Logs: Monitoring and Insights

We love content that draws engagement, and this contribution from @vikasparmar88 does just that! He writes about how to track replication-flow execution by accessing key metadata tables and diagnostic views within SAP Datasphere, and members are expressing their gratitude (and following up) in the comments.

Read the blog post

 

SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA: Pro Tips for SAP Fiori Demos

Long-time community contributor (and SAP employee) @Jocelyn_Dart is sharing tips and tricks for demonstrating SAP Fiori as a functional consultant. This post covers navigation. If you find it useful, make sure to check out SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA – Pro-tips for demonstrating SAP Fiori – Organizing your My Home page as well. More to come!

Read the blog post

 

SAP Business Data Cloud: Introduction and Deep Dive!

As the title suggests, this post from @NarasinghaPrasadPatro includes his thoughts about SAP Business Data Cloud. He covers what this solution delivers, its key features, how it differs from similar offerings, how partners are developing applications for it, and much more.

Read the blog post

 

Getting Started with Joule Studio in SAP Build

SAP’s @Diganta_Mandal kicked off a multi-part series designed to walk readers through the end-to-end setup and usage of Joule Studio. In part one, he focuses on provisioning -- laying the foundation for a successful Joule skill-development journey. (If you enjoy this post, make sure to check out the other parts of this series!)

Read the blog post

 

Community News

 

“Blog It Forward” Keeps Moving Forward!

The latest entry in our popular Blog It Forward series comes courtesy of SAP Mentor @Marla-Schwaiki. Get to know Marla by reading her post, and consider participating in this series yourself. You don’t need to wait for someone to nominate you! Check out this post for tips on structuring a “Blog It Forward”  contribution, then submit one of your own in the Community Corner blog board with the “Blog It Forward” label and user tag so other members can find your post. Also, subscribe to the Blog It Forward label so you get notifications whenever someone publishes a new entry. “Blog It Forward” is a great way for members to get to know you – and for you to connect with other members!

 

New Topic Pages

In the last few weeks, we have launched three new topic pages: SAP S/4HANA Selective Data Transition Engagement, Settlement Management, and SAP Engineering Control Center. If these subjects interest you, you’ll want to visit these pages for relevant content, as well as links to learning resources, useful tools, information about upcoming events, and more.

 

The Latest Fixes and Features

If you missed the What’s New post from Monday the 11th, here’s a reminder of the platform improvements introduced earlier this week. We added a new sort feature to the activity feeds for our Knowledge Base boards, fixed an issue with the general notifications feed, and (best of all) added share buttons to various content pages, making it easier for members to send links to SAP Community blog posts, discussions, and other contributions! See New Features and Fixes: Share Buttons, Notifications Feed, and More to get additional details about these updates.

 

Upcoming Events

 

Reasons to Attend SAP TechEd

SAP TechEd is returning in November with a hybrid experience. The in-person event in Berlin promises an amazing, educational time for attendees, but if you’re like SAP Champion @DanielMateo, you may be unable to make the trip. The good news is that you can still join the event virtually! Read Daniel’s Why I'm Attending SAP TechEd 2025 Virtually and Top Picks post to see why online participation might be a great option for you. SAP Community will have a big presence at SAP TechEd, so we look forward to seeing you – whether in Berlin or online!

 

Find SAP CodeJam Events in Your Region

SAP CodeJam events bring together developers who want hands-on learning for SAP technology, solutions, and applications. Next month, you can attend SAP CodeJam sessions in 's-Hertogenbosch (the Netherlands), Cologne (Germany), Mechelen (Belgium), Warsaw (Poland), Hamburg (Germany), and Porto (Portugal). Visit the SAP CodeJam activity group to learn more about these events, and check out the full list of upcoming events. Also, look for location groups near you, as these groups often host events as well.

entry.title: Data Replication framework- (DRF)
entry.content:
Key Concepts of SAP DRF Framework 

TermDescription
DRFData Replication Framework – a tool for distributing data from a source SAP system to one or more target systems.
Replication Model A configuration entity that defines what data to replicate, how to replicate it, and where to replicate it Outbound Implementation Logic that determines how data is extracted and structured for replication.
DRFOUTA transaction used to trigger outbound replication (manual or scheduled).
DRFIMGCustomizing transaction for setting up and maintaining the DRF configuration.
DRFFFramework that handles the formatting and technical transfer of replicated data.

Use Cases :

• Master Data Replication
→ Business Partner, Material, Customer, Vendor, Cost Center, etc.
• Integration with SAP MDG
→ Used to distribute governed master data to operational systems.
• Data Synchronization
→ For consistent master data across SAP S/4HANA and external systems (like CRM, SRM, SCM, CAR).
• Data Filtering & Transformation
→ Use Business Add-Ins (BAdIs) to filter data or transform it before replication.

Common Transactions Transaction Description
 

DRFOUTTrigger data replication manually or via batch jobs.
DRFIMG Configuration settings for DRF
DRFLOGView replication logs and errors.
DRFDUWDisplay replication status for objects.
SRT_MONIMonitor the Payloads


Replication Process Flow
1. Define Replication Model
  Select the data objects (e.g., Business Partner).
 Define filter criteria.
 Specify target systems.
2. Assign Outbound Implementation
Choose the replication method (IDoc, Web Service, etc.).
3. Schedule or Trigger Replication
Use DRFOUT to manually or automatically start replication.
4. Monitor
o Use DRFLOG, SLG1, or application-specific logs for troubleshooting.
Supported Technologies
• IDocs
• Web Services / SOA
• OData (with some S/4HANA scenarios)
• File-Based Transfers (rare, but possible)

entry.title: Re: Updating Customer in SAP S/4 HANA Public Cloud via OData HTTP Adapter
entry.content:
Hi @PatilGayatri,

It is indeed confusing browsing through all those services in SAP Business Hub. Great help for this is Postman, where you tune your calls against SAP S/4HANA directly. This is how you update the Customer Group for example. Of course you need to know the URL of the tenant where SAP S/4HANA resides.

Once you get the API calls right, you implement them in SCI as Request Reply adapters. Those input values (like "C5" in the screenshot) you usually get from the Sender, save them as properties and in the call you replace the actual value with that property.
And then you need to handle the response from SAP. If the call fails, you may want to notify somebody and pass the response message.

So in short - Get input data from Sender, get x-csrf token, pass data into API call, handle the response.
And you can build a separate iflow for each service - change address, change customer name, that will all be individual iflows.

entry.title: Re: BACs standard 18 setup in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud?
entry.content:
Hi @Monali 

For implementing a direct debit collection process in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition for UK customers using the BACS Standard 18 file format, here are some key points you should consider:

To enable you configure, activate the Direct Debit Mandate functionality in your S/4HANA Cloud via the Self-Service Configuration, then set up the payment method and payment terms to support direct debit with BACS procedure in the UK. Thereafter, define and assign the Direct Debit Mandate to business partners and company codes and configure bank data and house banks properly to support BACS.

To generate file and carry out testing, make sure to use the standard payment run and direct debit functionality to generate the BACS Standard 18 file. Before going live, perform test runs with sample mandate and bank data, validate the output file format, and confirm acceptance by your bank.

Below are Best Practices and Prerequisites in achieving that:

First, validate mandate management process end-to-end (creation, storage, revocation).

Then ensure customer bank account data and mandate references are accurate.

Engage early with your bank for format specifications and test file acceptance.

Finaly, Consider advance notices to customers before debit hits accounts.

 

I hope this provides the necessary information. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: JavaScript works in Adobe Form Designer for Check Pri...
entry.content:
1. By default the preview setting in Adobe LiveCycle Designer will create a dynamic pdf. Dynamic PDFs are rendered during runtime in Adobe Reader. That is why other readers (like chrome) will only show a static page prompting you to download the Adobe Reader. Adobe Reader has a different scripting engine then Adobe Document Services. So in order to get realistic results during the preview, switch it to static PDF output.
  2. There are quite a number of blogs on this platform that showcase this implementation (e.g. : https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-members/converting-amount-into-words-using-javascript-in-adobe/ba-p/13575021)
  3. See point 1. Switch the preview setting, so your preview output is aligned with the btp service.

entry.title: Re: Supplier and Purchasing group email not picked in PO...
entry.content:
Dear Lakshmipathi

Thanks for your reply Kindly refer to my comment within bolded bracket against your query.

Which CDS view is used for determining this supplier email address and purchasing group address? I have doubt whether these CDS view is not active. Hence system not able to determine email address and displaying code in email address field

Even if the email addresses are correct, SAP might still fail if: the sender email address is not mapped correctly in the Email Settings node. (Sender email address context is PURCHASINGGROUP)

The receiver email address is not being picked up due to missing or incorrect context mapping. (Receiver email address context is SUPPLIER)

Go to Output Parameter Determination → Email Settings and verify Sender email is explicitly defined. (If I maintain email address directly in output parameter determination app. It is working perfectly and mail send automatically. Issue occurs if context is maintained as PURCHASINGGROUP. Purchasing group code shown instead of email address)

Receiver email is mapped from the correct field (e.g., BusinessPartner.EmailAddress). (If I maintain email address directly in output parameter determination app. It is working perfectly and mail send automatically. Issue occurs if context is maintained as SUPPLIER. Supplier code shown instead of email address) Maintained email address in Business partner Communication section - email address

Check if the output type is configured to use EMAIL and not PRINT or XML by mistake. (EMAIL is maintained correctly)

SAP performs strict validation. Even small issues can trigger APOC_OR_MESSAGES105. Extra spaces before/after the email. Hidden characters (especially if copy-pasted). Multiple addresses in one field without proper separators. It is better to use transaction BP or SU01 and manually retype the email address. Avoid copy-paste. (Manually entered the email address. Still same issue)

Finally, Run SLG1 with: Object: APOC Subobject: OR_MESSAGES Date/time of the failed output Check the full message context—it often includes the exact field or logic that failed. (Application log app doesnot show any error message for output management)

Also try triggering the same output manually using Manage Output Items and see if the email is populated correctly. If it works manually but fails automatically, the issue is likely in the BRF+ determination logic. (If I maintain email address directly in output parameter determination app. It is working perfectly and mail send automatically.)

entry.title: SAP Integration SuiteのAI Adapterの使い方 Vol1.基本編
entry.content:
SAP IntegrationのAIアダプタがようやくリリースされたので試してみました。
この記事ではIntegration Suite AIアダプターの利用方法をステップバイステップで解説します。
AIアダプタの基本的な利用方法と、ChatGPTとの接続方法の解説、Content ModifierからテキストメッセージをAIアダプタに渡してレスポンスを取得します。

AI Adapterについて

AI Adapterはその名の通り、対話型AIとやり取りをするために利用するアダプタです。
2025年2Qにリリースされたばかりの新アダプタとなります。

・AI アダプタでは、 SAP AI Coreを利用したAICore-GenAIHubと、Chat GPT APIを利用したCustom-OpenAI-RESTの2 つのAI利用方法があります。

この記事では、後者のCustom-OpenAI-RESTを利用しAIアダプタを試してみます。

  1. Chat GPT APIの準備
  2. Integration Flow(iFlow)の作成
  3. 動作確認

1.Open AI API(Chat GPT API)の準備

1. Open AI API管理画面へのログイン

下記URLにアクセスしログインします
https://platform.openai.com/

2.ウィザードに従って組織(Organization)とプロジェクト(Project)を作成します

私の場合、組織:：MyDevTest、プロジェクト：SAPBTPと設定しました。

3.API Keyの作成

API Keyを作成します。後でBTPからAPIを呼び出すときにKeyを利用しますので、控えておいてください。

4.Open AI APIへの課金

Open AI APIをコールするには課金が必要です。課金しないと、APIをコールしても失敗してしまいます。
APIを1回コールするには大体0.01USDかかります。
クレジットカードを登録し、クレジットをチャージ(最低 5USD以上)します。

以上でOpen AI API側の準備は完了です。

2.Integration Flowの作成

1. API Keyの設定

Monitor -> Security Materials -> Create Secure Parameter
より、APIキーをセキュアパラメータとして設定します。
Name：OpenAI_APIKey
Secure Parameter：Bearer +API Key   例)Bearer sk-proj-MOuoJ8jxj.......

2.Integration Flowの作成

Integration Suiteのアップデートにより、Request ReplayコンポーネントからReceiverに線を引いたときに、『AI』アダプタが選択できるようになっています。

今回は下図のような簡単なiFlowを作成しました。それぞれのコンポーネントの設定値を解説していきます。

Start Timer：On Deploy (デプロイ時にトリガ)

Content Modifier：下図のように固定の文字列(AIへの質問)を設定しています。

AI Adapter(Connection)：API Key Aliasに先ほど作成したSecurity Materialsの『OpenAI_APIKey』を設定しています。

AI Adapter(Processing)：前のステップ(Content Modifier)で設定したメッセージボディをそのままAIに渡すため、プロンプトに${in.body}を設定します。

以上でIntegration Flowの作成は完了です。デプロイし動作確認してみます。

3.動作確認

実行したところ、下図のような応答が返ってきました。日本語での質問には日本語で返してくれます。

AIアダプタの基本的な使い方は以上となります。
本記事のようにメッセージボディをAIに流し込むことによって、データの要約をさせたり、システム連携時のエラーレスポンスをAIに分析させたりと、色々な応用ができそうではないでしょうか。

entry.title: Re: What is the minimum capacity units (CU) to activate Object Store in SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC
entry.content:
Unfortunately, that is not entirely accurate.

There is also a need to account for Compute Block-Hour and API Requests.

I enabled Object Store for testing purposes, allocating the minimum required resources: 1 TB of storage and 1 hour of compute time. To my surprise, simply enabling the service and creating a test space (for SAP HANA Data Lake Files) triggered messages indicating that the limits for API calls and compute hours had already been exceeded.

What’s particularly interesting is that I had no intention or need to use any APIs at this stage, yet over 5,000 API calls were registered. Why?

SAP needs to be more transparent and provide better documentation regarding this behavior.

I opened a ticket/incident to investigate, and support informed me that some scripts are executed by default, which may explain the unexpected consumption.

entry.title: Re: SAP S4/HANA Cloud Public, G/L account hierarchy 1799...
entry.content:
Hello @rekafulop 

If FSV 1799 is already created and assigned, but the Balance Validation still fails in J58, it generally indicates a mismatch between what the validation rule expects and what your FSV structure contains.

Check the settings below in the system

1. Full General Ledger account coverage in the FSV

  • GR/IR clearing accounts
  • Bank subaccounts and interim clearing accounts
  • Tax receivables/payables
  • Foreign currency valuation differences
  • Technical clearing accounts
  • Retained earnings & P&L carryforward accounts
    • In Manage Financial Statement Versions, ensure all balance sheet related G/L accounts are linked to nodes in 1799, including.
    • Any unassigned account with a non-zero balance will skew the equation.

2. Node type and sign consistency

    • Assets must be set as debit, Liabilities/Equity as credit (per standard SAP FSV logic).
    • If sign settings in the report variant are reversed from the validation rule, with credits shown as positive, the totals will appear mismatched.

3. Ledger and currency scope alignment

    • Run the validation for the same ledger and currency type used in your reporting local currency and group currency.
    • Make sure balance carry forward and all period-end closing activities are run for that ledger and currency.

4. Retained earnings linkage

    • Verify the retained earnings account is correctly included under Equity in 1799.
    • If omitted, Liabilities + Equity will be short by the net income amount.

5. Variant using FSV 1799

    • In the Balance Validation configuration, confirm the variant is pointing to FSV 1799, not the source FSV you copied from.
    • After copying, check that node types (Assets/Liabilities/Equity) stayed intact.

How to quickly identify the gap

Run G/L Account Balances Display for the same ledger/currency/period as J58.

Export the list of accounts and compare it to the account assignments in 1799.

Any non-zero balance account missing from the FSV should be added.

If the variance equals net income, check the retained earnings mapping.

Once all general ledger entries are correctly assigned and the signs are consistent, the J58 balance validation should succeed without any discrepancies.

Let me know if it works

With regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: Embedded RSSD compatibility and performance
entry.content:
Can you mix RSSD and eRSSD in the same replication domain? Yes

A couple caveats:

  • eRSSDs and routes; from the Repserver Admin Guide: You can create a route from a Replication Server with ERSSD, as long as both the source and the destination servers are version 15.0 or later
  • eRSSDs and standalone access; the eRSSD is shutdown when the repserver is shutdown; if you need to access the eRSSD while the repserver is down you'll need to either a) manually start the eRSSD (see startup command in the repserver's errorlog) or b) load a backup/copy of the eRSSD into a standalone SQLAnywhere database.

As for potential performance issues when using an eRSSD ...

  • regardless of whether you're using an eRSSD or RSSD, the repserver is constantly reading from, and writing to, the (e)RSSD; this means you'll want to insure the (e)RSSD is sitting on a fast (disk) device ... just like you would for any (production) database; since the repserver's stable queues (aka disk partitions) should be sitting on a fast (disk) device I typically place the eRSSD's data/log in its own directory on the same filesystem that contains the repserver's stable queues (see the rs.rs_erssd_database_dir and rs.rs_erssd_tranlog_dir settings in a rs_init resource file)
  • as for the daily volume of 15GB, how fast you can replicate that data is going to be based primarily on a) how the repserver is configured and b) the performance of the physical components, ie, cpus, memory, network, and disks (stable queues, (e)RSSD)

----------------------------

See this Q&A: Is there a method / what are steps to move from using RSSD to ERSSD in Replication Server  for a couple ideas on converting from RSSD to eRSSD. [Obviously run thorough testing before implementing in production.]

entry.title: Re: Automatically Start Sybase Database and SAP Application on the Same Host
entry.content:
FWIW ...

The backup server does not rely on the ASE dataserver so you could start the backup server right away (in the background) without needing to wait for the ASE dataserver to become available.

--------------------

While a hard coded 120-150 seconds of sleep is probably sufficient most times before starting the SAP application, there is a chance that a lengthy recovery operation (during ASE dataserver startup) could take more than 120-150 seconds; in this scenario the 'ps | grep | grep | grep' pipeline will show the ASE dataserver is up but the SAP application, upon starting, would find that its database(s) is not (yet) available.

A more accurate method for determining if the ASE dataserver is available would be to verify that the SAP application's database(s) is online.

One approach would be an isql script that issues the following 2x commands for each database the SAP application relies on:

  • use <sap_application_db_name>
  • select db_name() (should return <sap_application_db_name>)

An alternative approach would be to monitor the ASE dataserver's errorlog watching for messages of the format:

  • Database '<sap_application_db_name>' is now online.

The isql approach is probably simpler and would require a looping construct (eg, 5 second sleep on each pass through loop; after X passes if SAP application database(s) is not online then perform normal error/alerting steps).  The errorlog monitoring approach would be a tad more involved in that you would probably need a couple processes, one process to continuously tail/monitor the errorlog and one process to loop checking for results from the 1st process and then error/alert after X passes if the 'is now online' message(s) is not seen.

--------------------

A further refinement might see a separate service for the backup server,  the ASE dataserver, and the SAP application.  'course additional details like service ordering and dependencies would be required.

entry.title: Re: PCR valuation basis issue
entry.content:
Your system seems to be configured to have only 2 decimals, and SAP will usually round every number before the multiplication/division.

Could you create a Custom Valuation Basis that would be 100 times (or 1000 times) the "real" value so that you could then divide the result of PCR X115 by 100 (or 1000) or replace PCR X115 by Custom PCR Z115 that would incorporate a division by 100 (or 1000) before it's Output?

We've often used this work around, specially when the value of a Constant (in T511K) required more than 2 decimals.

entry.title: Re: RSH - Inable de change the navigation link of the wor...
entry.content:
Hello @RahmaLay 

In SAP S/4HANA Public cloud, the navigation links in the Work Details panel of the Resource Scheduling (RSH) dashboard are controlled by intent-based navigation in the Fiori Launchpad, not by direct configuration in SPRO.

To modify the link so it opens the IW32 Web GUI tile or its Fiori equivalent, Change Maintenance Order, follow the supported method:

  • Determine the semantic object and action associated with the Work Details link. Then, in the Launchpad Content Manager, set up a custom target mapping using the same semantic object and action, but direct it to the IW32 Web GUI app.
  • Place this target mapping in a custom catalogue and assign it to the business roles for your users.

When the user has both the standard and custom mapping, the system will use your custom mapping and launch IW32 instead. But if IW32 is not accessible as a Web GUI application within your Public Cloud scope, an alternative is to map it to the provided Fiori app for maintenance changes orders.

This method guarantees the change is upgrade-safe and adheres to Public Cloud extensibility rules, as direct modification of the delivered RSH app is not supported.

Kind regards,

Chuma Ofole

entry.title: Re: Service Order: Connection between service product and...
entry.content:
Hello @snigdhodeep 

You’re correct about the 42 CAD. It derives from the activity type rate linked to the cost center and activity type (SV01) combination. In S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, there is no mandatory service product associated with activity type SSCUI mapping; instead, the connection is indirect through the operation on the service order.

How the cost is determined

  1. Service order item → operation (from the service profile/template).
  2. Operation → activity type like SV01, defaulted via work center/control key/task list
  3. Activity type + cost center → planned price (maintained in Fiori).
  4. Planned cost = activity qty × activity price → shown as ongoing/baseline planned cost.

You can maintain/inspect rates here:

  • Edit Prices for Activity Types – Cost Centers (KP26) – planned prices per cost center and  activity type.
  • Manage Cost Rates – Services (optional) – service-order-specific rates; if maintained, they can drive planned cost.

A quick way to verify in your tenant

  1. Open your service order → Operations tab → check Activity Type (likely SV01).
  2. Open Edit Prices for Activity Types – Cost Centers and display the cost center + SV01 plan price for the relevant period, you should see 42 CAD.
  3. If you also manage Cost Rates – Services, verify whether a service-specific rate is set; if it is, that could be the source.

Let me know if it helps

With regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: Delete ariba CA SES in SAP MM
entry.content:
Hello @pratik_soni6 

In SAP S/4HANA Cloud or On-Premise integrated with Ariba Commerce Automation (CA), suppliers cannot directly delete Service Entry Sheets (SES) created through Ariba from backend tables (SE16N). Doing so is unsupported and may lead to serious data inconsistencies.

Key points to focus on for your case:

• Since the SES originates from Ariba CA, it follows the external approval and posting process.

• If no Material Document was created, and it remains in approval pending status, you can cancel it using the Manage Service Entry Sheets Fiori app (Public Cloud) or ML81N (On-Premises), provided you have the correct authorisations.

• If the approver user has left the organisation, reassign the workflow task to an active user via My Inbox – Workflow Administration or the Workflow Administration app.

• When workflow reassignment is not possible, the SES must be rejected in Ariba and resubmitted, which will withdraw it from SAP.

• Direct table deletion is never advised or supported (even in SE16N) because SES data is linked to follow-on documents and workflow logs.

Check this SAP Documentation KB0399151 - How do I cancel/ delete a service sheet as a supplier? 

Let me know it if helps

With regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: What does this error mean in ISLM?
entry.content:
Hello @Mithun_Kr 

The error message in ISLM (Intelligent Scenario Lifecycle Management) titled "Error occurred while creating model specification" is a generic front-end notification indicating that the system was unable to generate the model definition based on the parameters you provided.

How to troubleshoot

  1. Check the ST22 short dumps and SM21 system log immediately after reproducing the error, as the backend dump often contains the precise cause.
  2. Use transaction ISLM_ADMIN → Application Log to see detailed error logs for model creation.
  3. In HANA, review the trace files for _SYS_AFL calls — failures here will often indicate column not found, data type not supported,
  4. Validate datasets with a simple SELECT * in HANA to ensure all fields exist and have expected datatypes.

Field descriptions

These are documented in the SAP Help Portal for ISLM and APL:

  • Training Dataset → Table/View with historical data, including the target you want to predict.
  • Apply Dataset → Table/View where you want to apply the trained model to make predictions.
  • Target → Column in the Training Dataset you want to predict.
  • Keys → Columns that uniquely identify each record in the dataset (must be in both Training and Apply datasets).
  • Key Fields for Parameters → Columns used to parameterise scoring (e.g., document number, item number).


ISLM for Predictive Scenarios – SAP Help Portal
Automated Predictive Library (APL) – SAP HANA Academy

With regards

Chuma

entry.title: Integration of Sales Order Scheduling w/o sales order integration (basic)
entry.content:
I try to setup sales order scheduling based on TM transit time maintained in transportation lanes.

I followed instructions Integration of Sales Order Scheduling | SAP Help Portal but they are not clear to me.

I added a duration profile to the control key for sales orders.

It is stated that I do not need to integrate the sales order type etc to have this feature. So I did.

And this did not work. 😢

 

So I tried it with transportation relevance for my sales order type and sales org. I assigned a logistics integration profile w/o automatic FU building. Because in basic TM only delivery based FU are allowed.

Good, it worked. I get my scheduling in the sales order item. And no order-based freight unit is created. I create the outbound delivery and I get my FU for the delivery. Amazing! 🥳

Now, the sales order is increased (the same item for which a delivery exists already or a new item). 

I get a order-based freight unit. Terrible! ❌ This is advanced license!

Has someone set this up succesfully w/o touching the advanced license area?

How can SAP know for which I want a scheduling, when I don't assign the control key to the sales order type? 

The BPS schema is assigned to a control key and the control key is assigned to?

Thanks
